text: the civil war in Syria has raged for
more than five years more than a quarter
of a million people have been killed
this is said Nia prison a secret jail
where Amnesty International says
political opponents were held and
executed in their thousands the group
says it has evidence of an extermination
policy here ordered by the highest
levels of Syrian government once or
twice per week during the course of five
years between 2011 and 2015 20 to 50
prisoners are called upon they are
transported to another building on the
grounds of said Nia prison huddled into
an underground room and then they are
hanged the report is based on the
testimony of more than 80 former
prisoners and guards at the jail it
concludes between 2011 and 2015
between 5,000 and 13,000 detainees were
hanged there and their bodies buried in
mass graves on military land near
Damascus amnesty says the practices
inside the prison amounted to war crimes
and crimes against humanity and this
amnesty says is just one chilling
account from a farmer who was detained
at the prison for more than a year for
attending a peaceful protest and it has
Meraki I when they bring you food it
sounds like a battle in every cell they
take out the head of the cell or two
others to be beaten you hear sounds your
heart drops to the floor you begin to
shake you can't control it and this is
another former Syrian detainee Omar on
the left before his arrest and then on
the right after his release his weight
fell to just 35 kilograms President
Assad's government has previously denied
killing or mistreating detainees Amnesty
International says it contacted the
Syrian authorities about these
allegations in early January but has
received no response
Sarah cooker BBC News
